page.title: 14Humbleton
page.content: Many of the children travelling to school in Wooler come from small set- tlements scattered around the country- side.Humbleton is such a place,one mile north of Wooler.It is now almost a deserted village with only seven houses but it was at one time a consi- derable settlement around a triangular village green.The green is now covered by the remains of duck pond.The vill- age began to die when the lands of the small free-holders began to be gradua- lly absorbed by the the larger land owners. To the west of the village is Humbl- eton Hill,on top of which is a prehis- toric camp.Below this there is eviden- ce of three tiers of lynchets or cult- ivation terraces.All round the lower slopes are the remains of hut circles, cattle folds and oval tombs.
